Mayor Richard Daley's administration is making plans to limit the number of handguns allowed in Chicago homes as it grapples with a U.S. Supreme Court opinion gutting the city's long-standing gun ban.
 
 Each qualified gun owner in a home could have only one handgun under a new ordinance being drawn up that could be heard by the City Council Police and Fire Committee as soon as Thursday, officials said. The ordinance would require handgun owners to register their weapons with the Police Department and keep them secured inside the home.
 
 The measure also likely would force gun owners to take safety training classes, undergo a criminal background check and obtain liability insurance, city officials said. City Hall also is mulling a formal ban on gun shops, said Mara Georges, the city's top attorney.
 
 "Reducing the number of handguns in Chicago is critical to public safety," Georges said. "The same concerns that motivate a one handgun per person per residence limit - reducing the number of guns in circulation in Chicago and the risk of illegal traffic in guns - motivate the gun dealer ban."
 
 Chicago makes it tough to open a gun shop because the city has outlawed the display of guns for sale. There are no city stores that sell guns - but 45 suburban outlets that do within 13 miles of the city, Georges said.
 
 The scramble to pass new gun restrictions took place at a hearing the day after the U.S. Supreme Court struck down the city's gun ban, enacted under then-Mayor Jane Byrne in 1982. Despite the ban, Chicago continues to struggle with gun violence.
 
 City officials are trying not to cross a fine line. The Supreme Court ruled that citizens are entitled to keep handguns in their homes for self protection, but also said "reasonable" restrictions could be placed on handgun ownership.
 
 Pro-gun groups that backed the lawsuit overturning the ban said they are watching Chicago to make sure the restrictions are not unduly burdensome or costly to citizens exercising their Second Amendment rights as interpreted by a closely divided top court.

Doc, it's interesting that you bring up Michael Bellesiles. Although my PhD research was not on gun issues, I was a graduate student at Emory University when Michael was there, and I took a course with him on early America back around 1990. I remember us in the Emory History Department all watching in horror as his career evaporated, and he tried desperately to explain where his evidence came from. Things got really bizarre when he claimed that his notes were destroyed in a flood in his office. There was a flood in the building that affected his office, but I don't think anyone believed that the flood destroyed his notes. The whole thing was sad. I have lost touch with Michael, but I believe he is teaching in Connecticut now. Another colleague of ours, one of Michael's friends, said at the end, "Michael has lost his mind."
 
 I think Michael fell victim to hubris. He became so enamored of his own argument that he inflated his case way beyond what the evidence actually showed. As he became a superstar in a sense, winning awards and accolades and also drawing attacks from the NRA and its supporters, he grew less and less cautious, claiming that his probate evidence was central to sustaining his case. It turned out that he could not point to this evidence, and some of it he may have invented. Had he been more careful and less intent on confirming a stark and unambiguous argument, he might have sustained a modified version of his thesis with his other historical evidence. But he lost sight of caution and of the mission of the true scholar. A true scholar must look for the truth, whatever it is. A true scholar must never try to prove a pre-conceived belief. A true scholar must be open to what the evidence tells him or her, not exclude evidence that does not confirm his or her argument. And a true scholar must never inflate evidence or make it up.
 
 In answer to your other questions and points, my interest here is mainly in how the Supreme Court rules in regard to the 14th amendment and incorporation, not in gun control laws specifically. I really do not care particularly what gun control laws states or cities pass. 
 
 It is true that the Supreme Court has not, over time, interpreted individual rights as being absolute. They have created balancing tests, and they have ruled on exceptions to individual rights. Even the first amendment right of free speech, which the Supreme Court has usually been careful to protect, has not been interpreted by the Court as being absolute. We have laws against slander and libel. And we have seen the Court wade into that ambiguous terrain of pornography and what can and cannot be banned. Whether you and I agree with the Supreme Court that rights are not absolute is a different question and one that I don't care to get into. I am simply observing that the Supreme Court is likely to rule that gun regulations are constitutional, but not outright bans, such as the one that existed in Chicago. What regulations the Court deems constitutional will be the big new question. 
 
 My other interest in posting here is to hear from Steeeve again, as I have always enjoyed our arguments about constitutional interpretation, though in the past they took place in other threads.
 
 Do I personally support the individual right to bear arms? Yes, but only because it is in the constitution, and now the Supreme Court has ruled that this is an individual right and the right is protected from state abrogation. I think this was the right ruling, though I wish the Court majority had incorporated the amendment through the privileges and immunities clause. I am certainly not going to oppose people's right to bear arms. It really does not matter much to me. I understand that many other people have passionate feelings about this, and that's fine. Also, I do not think Michael's "sole purpose" in writing "Arming America" was "agenda-based political activism." My take on this, as someone who knew Michael at the time, is that he was trying to become a superstar among scholars, to enhance his reputation by writing a history that would debunk what he viewed as popular myths about guns in the nation's past. Michael was never, from what I recall, a political activist particularly. He was and apparently still is ambitious, and I think he was motivated by that ambition. He wanted to make a big splash academically with his book, and he did. At first, he drew fire from the NRA, and that only enhanced his reputation in scholarly circles. But then, when James Lindgren challenged the probate data, he made a splash because of his downfall. 
 
 I am not defending Michael here. I am trying to illuminate what I think motivated him. I remember Michael as extremely ambitious and energetic, as someone who was in a hurry to publish a ground-breaking book that would change how scholars and ordinary Americans think about the history of guns in our nation. I think he hoped to win the esteem of his colleagues. I think he believed then and probably still believes that he was right about gun ownership in early America. But the question of whether or not his argument, with qualifications, may be right got lost when he could not produce the probate evidence, and when his explanations in defense of his book gradually fell apart. 
 
 He did not, btw, resign as soon as the questions about his scholarship emerged. He engaged in a lengthy effort to defend his research, an effort that seemed only to make things worse. He resigned after the investigating committee issued its report.
